text: This is Solomon’s song of songs, more wonderful than any other.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kiss me and kiss me again,
    for your love is sweeter than wine.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Take me with you; come, let’s run!
    The king has brought me into his bedroom.
How happy we are for you, O king.
    We praise your love even more than wine.
How right they are to adore you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am dark but beautiful,
    O women of Jerusalem—
dark as the tents of Kedar,
    dark as the curtains of Solomon’s tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t stare at me because I am dark—
    the sun has darkened my skin.
My brothers were angry with me;
    they forced me to care for their vineyards,
    so I couldn’t care for myself—my own vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell me, my love, where are you leading your flock today?
    Where will you rest your sheep at noon?
For why should I wander like a prostitute
    among your friends and their flocks?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you don’t know, O most beautiful woman,
    follow the trail of my flock,
    and graze your young goats by the shepherds’ tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are as exciting, my darling,
    as a mare among Pharaoh’s stallions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How lovely are your cheeks;
    your earrings set them afire!
How lovely is your neck,
    enhanced by a string of jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We will make for you earrings of gold
    and beads of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king is lying on his couch,
    enchanted by the fragrance of my perfume.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover is like a sachet of myrrh
    lying between my breasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is like a bouquet of sweet henna blossoms
    from the vineyards of En-gedi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful you are, my darling,
    how beautiful!
    Your eyes are like doves.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
fragrant cedar branches are the beams of our house,
    and pleasant smelling firs are the rafters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the spring crocus blooming on the Sharon Plain,
    the lily of the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a lily among thistles
    is my darling among young women.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the finest apple tree in the orchard
    is my lover among other young men.
I sit in his delightful shade
    and taste his delicious fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He escorts me to the banquet hall;
    it’s obvious how much he loves me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strengthen me with raisin cakes,
    refresh me with apples,
    for I am weak with love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His left arm is under my head,
    and his right arm embraces me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Promise me, O women of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles and wild deer,
    not to awaken love until the time is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ah, I hear my lover coming!
    He is leaping over the mountains,
    bounding over the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover is like a swift gazelle
    or a young stag.
Look, there he is behind the wall,
    looking through the window,
    peering into the room.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover said to me,
    “Rise up, my darling!
    Come away with me, my fair one!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, the winter is past,
    and the rains are over and gone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The flowers are springing up,
    the season of singing birds has come,
    and the cooing of turtledoves fills the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fig trees are forming young fruit,
    and the fragrant grapevines are blossoming.
Rise up, my darling!
    Come away with me, my fair one!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My dove is hiding behind the rocks,
    behind an outcrop on the cliff.
Let me see your face;
    let me hear your voice.
For your voice is pleasant,
    and your face is lovely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Catch all the foxes,
    those little foxes,
before they ruin the vineyard of love,
    for the grapevines are blossoming!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover is mine, and I am his.
    He browses among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the dawn breezes blow
    and the night shadows flee,
return to me, my love, like a gazelle
    or a young stag on the rugged mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One night as I lay in bed, I yearned for my lover.
    I yearned for him, but he did not come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I said to myself, “I will get up and roam the city,
    searching in all its streets and squares.
I will search for the one I love.”
    So I searched everywhere but did not find him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchmen stopped me as they made their rounds,
    and I asked, “Have you seen the one I love?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then scarcely had I left them
    when I found my love!
I caught and held him tightly,
    then I brought him to my mother’s house,
    into my mother’s bed, where I had been conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Promise me, O women of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles and wild deer,
    not to awaken love until the time is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this sweeping in from the wilderness
    like a cloud of smoke?
Who is it, fragrant with myrrh and frankincense
    and every kind of spice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, it is Solomon’s carriage,
    surrounded by sixty heroic men,
    the best of Israel’s soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all skilled swordsmen,
    experienced warriors.
Each wears a sword on his thigh,
    ready to defend the king against an attack in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Solomon’s carriage is built
    of wood imported from Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its posts are silver,
    its canopy gold;
    its cushions are purple.
It was decorated with love
    by the young women of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come out to see King Solomon,
    young women of Jerusalem.
He wears the crown his mother gave him on his wedding day,
    his most joyous day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are beautiful, my darling,
    beautiful beyond words.
Your eyes are like doves
    behind your veil.
Your hair falls in waves,
    like a flock of goats winding down the slopes of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your teeth are as white as sheep,
    recently shorn and freshly washed.
Your smile is flawless,
    each tooth matched with its twin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your lips are like scarlet ribbon;
    your mouth is inviting.
Your cheeks are like rosy pomegranates
    behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is as beautiful as the tower of David,
    jeweled with the shields of a thousand heroes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your breasts are like two fawns,
    twin fawns of a gazelle grazing among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the dawn breezes blow
    and the night shadows flee,
I will hurry to the mountain of myrrh
    and to the hill of frankincense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are altogether beautiful, my darling,
    beautiful in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come with me from Lebanon, my bride,
    come with me from Lebanon.
Come down from Mount Amana,
    from the peaks of Senir and Hermon,
where the lions have their dens
    and leopards live among the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have captured my heart,
    my treasure, my bride.
You hold it hostage with one glance of your eyes,
    with a single jewel of your necklace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your love delights me,
    my treasure, my bride.
Your love is better than wine,
    your perfume more fragrant than spices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your lips are as sweet as nectar, my bride.
    Honey and milk are under your tongue.
Your clothes are scented
    like the cedars of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are my private garden, my treasure, my bride,
    a secluded spring, a hidden fountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your thighs shelter a paradise of pomegranates
    with rare spices—
henna with nard,
speaker: Narrator

text:
nard and saffron,
    fragrant calamus and cinnamon,
with all the trees of frankincense, myrrh, and aloes,
    and every other lovely spice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are a garden fountain,
    a well of fresh water
    streaming down from Lebanon’s mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, north wind!
    Rise up, south wind!
Blow on my garden
    and spread its fragrance all around.
Come into your garden, my love;
    taste its finest fruits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have entered my garden, my treasure, my bride!
    I gather myrrh with my spices
and eat honeycomb with my honey.
    I drink wine with my milk.
Oh, lover and beloved, eat and drink!
    Yes, drink deeply of your love!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I slept, but my heart was awake,
    when I heard my lover knocking and calling:
“Open to me, my treasure, my darling,
    my dove, my perfect one.
My head is drenched with dew,
    my hair with the dampness of the night.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I responded,
“I have taken off my robe.
    Should I get dressed again?
I have washed my feet.
    Should I get them soiled?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover tried to unlatch the door,
    and my heart thrilled within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I jumped up to open the door for my love,
    and my hands dripped with perfume.
My fingers dripped with lovely myrrh
    as I pulled back the bolt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I opened to my lover,
    but he was gone!
    My heart sank.
I searched for him
    but could not find him anywhere.
I called to him,
    but there was no reply.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The night watchmen found me
    as they made their rounds.
They beat and bruised me
    and stripped off my veil,
    those watchmen on the walls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make this promise, O women of Jerusalem—
    If you find my lover,
    tell him I am weak with love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why is your lover better than all others,
    O woman of rare beauty?
What makes your lover so special
    that we must promise this?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover is dark and dazzling,
    better than ten thousand others!
speaker: Narrator

text:
His head is finest gold,
    his wavy hair is black as a raven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes sparkle like doves
    beside springs of water;
they are set like jewels
    washed in milk.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His cheeks are like gardens of spices
    giving off fragrance.
His lips are like lilies,
    perfumed with myrrh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His arms are like rounded bars of gold,
    set with beryl.
His body is like bright ivory,
    glowing with lapis lazuli.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His legs are like marble pillars
    set in sockets of finest gold.
His posture is stately,
    like the noble cedars of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His mouth is sweetness itself;
    he is desirable in every way.
Such, O women of Jerusalem,
    is my lover, my friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where has your lover gone,
    O woman of rare beauty?
Which way did he turn
    so we can help you find him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lover has gone down to his garden,
    to his spice beds,
to browse in the gardens
    and gather the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my lover’s, and my lover is mine.
    He browses among the lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are beautiful, my darling,
    like the lovely city of Tirzah.
Yes, as beautiful as Jerusalem,
    as majestic as an army with billowing banners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your eyes away,
    for they overpower me.
Your hair falls in waves,
    like a flock of goats winding down the slopes of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your teeth are as white as sheep
    that are freshly washed.
Your smile is flawless,
    each tooth matched with its twin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your cheeks are like rosy pomegranates
    behind your veil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even among sixty queens
    and eighty concubines
    and countless young women,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would still choose my dove, my perfect one—
    the favorite of her mother,
    dearly loved by the one who bore her.
The young women see her and praise her;
    even queens and royal concubines sing her praises:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this, arising like the dawn,
    as fair as the moon,
as bright as the sun,
    as majestic as an army with billowing banners?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went down to the grove of walnut trees
    and out to the valley to see the new spring growth,
to see whether the grapevines had budded
    or the pomegranates were in bloom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before I realized it,
    my strong desires had taken me to the chariot of a noble man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, return to us, O maid of Shulam.
    Come back, come back, that we may see you again.
Why do you stare at this young woman of Shulam,
    as she moves so gracefully between two lines of dancers?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How beautiful are your sandaled feet,
    O queenly maiden.
Your rounded thighs are like jewels,
    the work of a skilled craftsman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your navel is perfectly formed
    like a goblet filled with mixed wine.
Between your thighs lies a mound of wheat
    bordered with lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your breasts are like two fawns,
    twin fawns of a gazelle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your neck is as beautiful as an ivory tower.
Your eyes are like the sparkling pools in Heshbon
    by the gate of Bath-rabbim.
Your nose is as fine as the tower of Lebanon
    overlooking Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your head is as majestic as Mount Carmel,
    and the sheen of your hair radiates royalty.
    The king is held captive by its tresses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, how beautiful you are!
    How pleasing, my love, how full of delights!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are slender like a palm tree,
    and your breasts are like its clusters of fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, “I will climb the palm tree
    and take hold of its fruit.”
May your breasts be like grape clusters,
    and the fragrance of your breath like apples.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May your kisses be as exciting as the best wine—
Yes, wine that goes down smoothly for my lover,
    flowing gently over lips and teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am my lover’s,
    and he claims me as his own.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, my love, let us go out to the fields
    and spend the night among the wildflowers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us get up early and go to the vineyards
    to see if the grapevines have budded,
if the blossoms have opened,
    and if the pomegranates have bloomed.
    There I will give you my love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the mandrakes give off their fragrance,
    and the finest fruits are at our door,
new delights as well as old,
    which I have saved for you, my lover.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, I wish you were my brother,
    who nursed at my mother’s breasts.
Then I could kiss you no matter who was watching,
    and no one would criticize me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would bring you to my childhood home,
    and there you would teach me.
I would give you spiced wine to drink,
    my sweet pomegranate wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your left arm would be under my head,
    and your right arm would embrace me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Promise me, O women of Jerusalem,
    not to awaken love until the time is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this sweeping in from the desert,
    leaning on her lover?
I aroused you under the apple tree,
    where your mother gave you birth,
    where in great pain she delivered you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Place me like a seal over your heart,
    like a seal on your arm.
For love is as strong as death,
    its jealousy as enduring as the grave.
Love flashes like fire,
    the brightest kind of flame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
    nor can rivers drown it.
If a man tried to buy love
    with all his wealth,
    his offer would be utterly scorned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have a little sister
    too young to have breasts.
What will we do for our sister
    if someone asks to marry her?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If she is a virgin, like a wall,
    we will protect her with a silver tower.
But if she is promiscuous, like a swinging door,
    we will block her door with a cedar bar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a virgin, like a wall;
    now my breasts are like towers.
When my lover looks at me,
    he is delighted with what he sees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Solomon has a vineyard at Baal-hamon,
    which he leases out to tenant farmers.
Each of them pays a thousand pieces of silver
    for harvesting its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my vineyard is mine to give,
    and Solomon need not pay a thousand pieces of silver.
But I will give two hundred pieces
    to those who care for its vines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my darling, lingering in the gardens,
    your companions are fortunate to hear your voice.
    Let me hear it, too!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come away, my love! Be like a gazelle
    or a young stag on the mountains of spices.
speaker: Narrator
